contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=January 2009}} {{Japanese city| Name = Tagajō City| JapaneseName = 多賀城市| Region = [[Tōhoku Region|Tōhoku]]| Prefecture = [[Miyagi Prefecture]]| MapImage=Tagajo in Miyagi Prefecture - Ja.svg| Area_km2 = 19.64 | Population = 63,256 | PopDate = 2010 | Density_km2 = 3.220 | Mayor = Kikuchi Kenjirou | Coords= | LatitudeDegrees= 38| LatitudeMinutes= 17| LatitudeSeconds= 39| LongtitudeDegrees= 141| LongtitudeMinutes= 0| LongtitudeSeconds= 16| Tree = Camellia sasanqua| Flower = Iris sanguinea| Bird = | SymbolImage=Flag of Takajo Miyagi.JPG| CityHallPostalCode = 985-8531| CityHallAddress=Tagajō-shi, <br>Chūō Ni-chōme 1-1| CityHallPhone=022-368-1141| CityHallLink = [http://www.city.tagajo.miyagi.jp/ City of Tagajō]| }} {{Nihongo|'''Tagajō'''|多賀城市|Tagajō-shi}} is a [[cities of Japan|city]] located in [[Miyagi Prefecture]], Japan. The city was named after [[Site of Tagajō|Taga Castle]], the capital of [[Mutsu Province]]. As of 2010, the city has an estimated [[population]] of 63,256 and the [[population density]] of 3,220 persons per km². The total area is 19.64 km². The present day city was founded on November 1, 1971. The [[869 Jogan Sanriku earthquake|tsunami in 869]] caused extensive flooding of the Sendai plain, destroying the town of Tagajō. Archaeological investigations have identified the remains of 8th and 9th century buildings beneath the present town, covered by sediments dated to the middle of the 10th century.<ref name="Minoura">{{cite journal|last=Minoura|first=K.|coauthors=[[Fumihiko Imamura|Imamura F.]], Sugawara D., Kono Y. & Iwashita T.|year=2001|title=The 869 Jōgan tsunami deposit and recurrence interval of large-scale tsunami on the Pacific coast of northeast Japan|journal=Journal of Natural Disaster Science|volume=23|issue=2|pages=83–88|url=http://wwwsoc.nii.ac.jp/jsnds/contents/jnds/23_2_3.pdf|accessdate=12 March 2011}}</ref> The town was again seriously affected by the [[tsunami]] caused by the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake]].<ref>http://www.thedailynewsegypt.com/world/japan-quake-tsunami-death-toll-likely-over-10000-dp1.html Japan quake-tsunami death toll likely over 10,000</ref> As of 7 April 2011, 177 people were known dead, with 15 missing. 1,811 people were living in shelters.<ref>Aoki, Mizuho, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110407f2.html U.S. teacher stays to return favor to helpful residents of Miyagi town]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 7 April 2011, p. 3.</ref> ==Economy== [[Sony]] operates the Sendai Technology Center in Tagajō.<ref>"[http://www.sony.net/SonyInfo/CorporateInfo/Data/Map/index.html Access & Map]."
